Commentary on current proposal

This is a version of the third option below. As mechanics it has the advantages of being expandable but not causing skill bloat (skills for schools, specializations for spells), being expandable without being complex (multiple schools with individual bases, multiple bases with scalable effects and costs), and being limited without being crippling (xp & use costs create a power curve). Thematically, it ties to the PT world and helps to flavor the three major civilizations better than most less tethered options would.Darker Dreams 07:50, 4 July 2008 (CEST)

Core system

design options;

Option 1

Spells as skills:

Each spell is a skill in its own right, the caster simply needs to spend the resources necessarry and succeed at a check.

Pro; Makes it difficult for casters to become overwhelmingly powerful. Clear system.

Con; Makes each skill weaker than any other skill, leads to a proliferation of skills.

Option 2

One skill, learned spells;

A single "magic" skill is checked for all spells. Spells are learned through some other system.

Pro; limits skill proliferation.

Con; Makes spellcasters entirely relient on cash for power instead of a balance between funds and experience like warriors.


Option 3

Multiple "schools," learned spells.

Between 3 and 10 schools each with it's own "portfolio" of effects.

Pro; Limited skill proliferation, balances between needing Xp and funds to gain power.

Con; how do you divide it up? Elemental (which system)? Color (which system)? Other?


New spells

How does a player learn a new spell?

How does the player create a unique spell?


Dividing spells up into categories

Basically, color systems and elemental systems both are attempts to group spells with similar functions or effects together. I've been thinking about this matter for a little while now and have come up with an elemental system of sorts:

  • Light--controls both light and shadows
  • Fire--direct control of heat/temperature + combustion
  • Lightning--controls electricity (static + current) and magnetism
  • Water--direct control of water in all phases (ice, liquid, steam, perhaps supercritical)
  • Air--control over weather and air itself (can even change its composition locally when in the right hands), also controls pressure/vacuum
  • Life--control over life and death
  • Time--controls time, space, and motion
  • Mind--controls will of creatures, perception, and persuasion

the above was submitted by User:Kaerli

commentary starts here

I am unsure how this is superior to the current proposal. From my point of view, what's described here seems like an underdeveloped version of what's already proposed. This also seems significantly removed from the intended focus of the game (the three portals). Some examples of how this schema has already been superseded by the current proposal include; The "Life" sphere/element constitutes the majority of the "Necromancy" school, though "mind" also finds a home under that umbrella. "Time" is the essence of the Wizardry school. Fire, Water, Air are all covered- in almost precisely this form, including subdivision -in Sorcery, along with the omitted "Earth" element (which, I assume, you omitted due to its problematic nature) giving that "type" of magic much greater overall utility than any one element without loosing the elemental focus. Similarly, Light and Lightning each seem significantly constrained in their utility. Meanwhile, this entirely omits discussion of any sort of magic item creation/modification, and provides no obvious routs of expansion for magic outside of warping the underlaying theme of a category or "simply" adding new categories. Finally, I do not feel that this is particularly unique when compared to the array of "elemental" systems present in games, particularly the Final Fantasy series of games. In short; while it would take significant development of an idea above the level this has reached for me to seriously consider replacing the current proposal with a new one, I am unconvinced that even were this idea sufficiently developed it would be superior to the current proposal on any of the following criteria; A) fitting the Peragro Tempus focus (three portals). B) Covering a significant portion of the possible and desirable magic effects. C) Creating a manageable scheme of skills without making the accumulation of personal power too easy. D) Providing a scheme that is recognizably unique to PT. Darker Dreams 06:37, 23 April 2008 (CEST)

When my first round of critique is barely a paragraph, and that's longer than your proposal to replace something that's already up- your proposal is probably underdeveloped. Darker Dreams 07:06, 23 April 2008 (CEST)
